Package com.esri.mo2.data.gcd

Interfaces and classes defining API for geocoding.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
GcdFactory Defines an interface for creating and accessing instances of Geocoder, GcdStyle and PropertySequence interfaces.
GcdStyle Defines an interface for accessing properties of a geocoding style.
Geocoder Defines an interface for geocoding addresses.
PropertySequence Defines an ordered collection of properties where each property is a pair of a name and an associated value.
 

Class Summary
BasePropertySequence A default implementation of the PropertySequence interface.
FieldEntry Combines different properties of data fields used by a geocoder.
 

Exception Summary
GeocoderException Defines exceptions that are thrown if something goes wrong while geocoding.
 

Package com.esri.mo2.data.gcd Description

Interfaces and classes defining API for geocoding.

Notes on Notation

To augment documentation of functionally complicated interfaces and classes we used in this package the notions of an explicit invariant and of method preconditions and postconditions.

An invariant is a predicate (boolean-valued expression) expressed either on member variables of a class directly or using methods of this and related classes. An invariant restricts a set of all states an instance of a class can possibly assume. An invariant is a predicate that an author of the specification/documentation believes would evaluate to true in a state immediately after the completion of the class constructor and before and after execution of each public method of the class. In other words, if Java assertion statements containing an invariant were inserted in the end of each class constructor and, respectively, preceding and trailing bodies of each public method, they would pass without throwing an error on every run of the program.

A method precondition is a predicate expressed either on member variables of the class or using methods of this and related classes. A method precondition restricts a set of states an instance of the class can be in for this operation to execute correctly. A method precondition can be thought of as a boolean-valued expression enclosed in a Java assertion statement that is attached immediately in front of the method body. Such an assertion statement should pass without throwing an error on every run of this method.

Similarly, a method postcondition is a predicate expressed either on member variables of the class or using methods of this and related classes. A method postcondition describes a set of states an instance of the class must be in after the execution of this method. A method postcondition can be thought of as a boolean-valued expression enclosed in a Java assertion statement that is attached immediately after the method body. Such an assertion statement should pass without throwing an error on every run of this method.

It has to be mentioned that we use invariants and pre/post-conditions as a specification/documentation aid. As such, they do not have to be deterministic or be expressed in terms of executable statements. While Java interfaces do not have any member variables, the usage of invariants and pre/post-conditions is still very beneficial for the specification/documentation of the intended functionality of the interface since it permits expressing the semantics of the interface, which otherwise is expressed only in class and method names of this interface.

For those developers familiar with ideas of the weakest precondition calculus developed by E.W. Dijkstra, we would like to point out that the preconditions used in our documentation are not the weakest preconditions of the respective operations. A weakest precondition WP of a method M with respect to a postcondition POST is usually defined to be such that if a method M is executed in a state satisfying WP the state after the execution of M is guaranteed to satisfy POST. The preconditions that can be found in our specification do not comply with this definition and are there for documentation purposes only. These preconditions are supposed to help with explicitly capturing the assumptions made by method developers. Note that if the documented assumptions of the developers are not met, there is a very little chance of the method in question to operate correctly. Similarly, the postconditions in our documentation are there to help document the guarantees on the results of the methods. We would like to point out that the idea of specifying and documenting object-oriented programs using invariants and pre/post-conditions is widely used in the research community as well as in industry. In particular, invariants and pre/post-conditions are the central concept in the Design by Contract method as developed by Bertrand Meyer (http://www.eiffel.com/doc/oosc/page.html). Invariants and pre/post-conditions are also featured in the Object Constraint Language, which is the expression language for the UML (http://www-3.ibm.com/software/ad/library/standards/ocl.html).

In our documentation we suggest writing the invariants and the pre/post-conditions either in plain English (informally), or in terms of calls to methods of the class under consideration and related classes (an algebraic style), or a combination of these two approaches.

We use <==> to indicate equality between two objects. We define object equality as follows: for any objects a and b, a <==> b if they refer to the same object or if all fields in these objects are respectively equal, or if a and b are instances of simple types (e.g., int, char) and their values are equal. For example, for java.lang.String s1 and java.lang.String s2, s1 <==> s2 holds when s1.equals(s2) returns true. We will continue using the Java symbol for equality "==" when comparing for equality elements of simple types, such as integers.

We use ==> to denote the boolean implication operation. An implication a ==> b is TRUE if a is TRUE and b is TRUE or if a is FALSE.
